I didn't really have expectations going into GoT, and for the first few hours it didn't blow me away. When the story properly kicks off, it is very good from a few hours in to the end. They deal with open world quest objectives in a creative way where the direction the wind blows in is the direction you're meant to go in. It's not in your face, it's not a compass with a big yellow arrow on it that says "GO HERE". All direction you're given feels more like guidance than telling you what to do. 

It does suffer from the common problem in action games where the combat can feel shallow in the beginning, but as you get a grip of the mechanics and unlock more "abilities" you can mix up each fight massively. You switch between stances in a way that's not clunky, you have batman-like gadgets as well as your sword and bow, everything feels so fluid and smooth to use. When you get the ability that lets you use slow-mo when aiming your bow it becomes even more fluid where you can headshot multiple people from a few feet away in under a second the instantly throw down a smoke bomb and assassinate another two - it's more thrilling than I'm giving it credit for and that's just one of many "techniques" you can use. Ghost of Tsushima is what assassins creed has been trying to be, but Ghost does a far better job since the AC quests are quests where you tick a box by gathering an item or clearing out this camp of bandits or deliver this thing to this person - Ghost has absolutely none of the tedium. There are bandit (mongol) camps to clear out in quests but you're not doing it to retrieve an item, there is always a story justification or a character you're helping with a longer quest so it feels like it has purpose. 

I loved the second 2/3 of the story, but the first 1/3 does feel slow as there's a lot of travelling around meeting new characters and learning their stories. They're all very cool but traversal in the first chapter I felt was more tedious than the second two. I still enjoyed it a lot but the first chapter is the weakest in my opinion. Each character has it's own set of story quests to follow where you help them avenge someone or hunt someone down or something like that. Without spoiling I found Masako's quests to be a slog after the first couple. While she's a good character her story is the most generic (not bad). 

The main antagonist is the leader of the mongol invasion, and his soldiers. The music is a cool mix of Mongolian throat singing and the type of music you'd expect in a Samurai game. It's a cool blend of cultures since the Mongols have already taken over certain areas and you get to see their culture next to the Japanese. I liked the enemy variety as well, the way that you deal with each enemy type keeps encounters fresh. 

The DLC has a very cool story where you confront something which is mentioned in the main game several times, it fits into the base game very seamlessly and there is a good amount of content on the new island. 

Overall it's a nice breath of fresh air in a world of open world RPGs - it has some RPG elements but you're not levelling up and distributing your points. It's first and foremost an action game, and I think it deserves it's reputation as one of the best.

In a genre saturated with cluttered maps and repetitive checklists, Ghost of Tsushima stands apart not by reinventing the wheel, but by perfecting it. It is a game that understands the value of silence, atmosphere, and the weight of a sword swing. It is not just an open-world game; it is a cinematic experience that pays homage to classic samurai cinema while telling a deeply personal story of sacrifice.

The Narrative: Honor vs. Necessity, At its core, the story is a poignant tragedy. It isn't simply about defeating the Mongol invasion; it is about the internal deconstruction of Jin Sakai. The writing brilliantly explores the conflict between rigid tradition (The Samurai Code) and the harsh reality of war (The Ghost). Watching Jin‚Äôs relationship with his uncle, Lord Shimura, slowly fracture is heartbreaking and is easily one of the best narrative arcs in modern gaming.

The most revolutionary aspect of this game is the lack of a intrusive HUD. Replacing a mini-map with the "Guiding Wind" changes the entire feel of exploration. Instead of staring at a compass in the corner of the screen, you are looking at the world itself‚Äîwatching the grass bend and the leaves swirl. This immersion makes the island of Tsushima feel like a living character rather than just a backdrop.

Combat is visceral, grounded, and incredibly satisfying. It strikes a perfect balance between accessibility and depth. The "Stance" system encourages tactical thinking, while the parry mechanics reward patience and precision. Every strike feels lethal. Whether you choose to face enemies head-on with an Honorable Standoff or strike from the shadows as the Ghost, the gameplay loop never gets stale.

For PC players, this port is nothing short of a miracle. It is exceptionally optimized. The addition of ultrawide support, unlocked framerates, and upscale technologies (DLSS/FSR) makes an already beautiful game look generational. It runs buttery smooth, proving that good optimization is still possible in 2024.

Ghost of Tsushima is a triumph of aesthetic and design. It is a love letter to feudal Japan and Kurosawa films. It reminds us that sometimes, to save what we hold dear, we must become something else entirely.

[h1]Ghost of Tsushima - A Journey Beyond the Sword[/h1]  

When I started *Ghost of Tsushima*, I thought it would be a straightforward samurai story, but it became so much more. The world feels alive, the pacing is perfect, and almost everything you do feels rewarding.  

Fast travel is almost instant, making exploration effortless. The combat hits a great balance between swordplay and stealth, and once you get used to the guiding wind mechanic, it feels natural. Stealth kills and aerial assassinations give that *Assassin‚Äôs Creed* feel but with more precision and grace, very samurai in execution.  

I love how easy resource gathering is. You can collect materials while riding your horse without stopping, which keeps the flow going. Even slightly distant items get auto-collected, a small but great quality-of-life touch.  

Shrines reminded me of *Tomb Raider*, small climbing challenges that never get frustrating, just fun. Each climb feels like a short, rewarding detour.  

The only thing that threw me off early was the fog-of-war map. I initially thought I had to uncover every inch manually, but once I realized liberating red areas clears big sections, it all made sense. It ended up feeling pretty smooth and natural by the end.  

The story hits the right notes emotionally. You really feel the weight of Jin‚Äôs choices and his gradual shift between tradition and survival. Performances are excellent and the voice acting sells every moment.  

[b]Note:[/b] The English voice acting is highly recommended. The lip sync and tone feel more natural here.

I‚Äôm finally getting around to this a good five years after release, and honestly, I definitely slept on it. Is it as good as everyone hyped it up to be? Not really. But it is close, and still a damn good game so far.

At its core, Ghost of Tsushima feels pretty similar to a typical "Ubisoft-style" open world game. Big map, loads of missions, side objectives everywhere, random encounters popping up as you travel around. The difference is that this one actually has style, atmosphere and polish, because Ubisoft didn‚Äôt make it.

Gameplay and progression

You get everything from small sword fights to big group battles, ranged combat with bows, kunai and black powder bombs, stealth kills, distraction items, crafting upgrades, duels and all sorts of little activities around the island. There is always something happening.

You unlock a steady stream of skills and weapon upgrades as you go. New stances, abilities, ghost tools, armour sets with perks, charms, all that stuff. It creates a really solid loop of explore, fight, upgrade, get stronger. Nothing mind blowing, but very well put together, satisfying and fun.

Enemy variety gets better as the game goes on. You start off with basic sword guys, then you get shield users, spear guys, brutes, archers, dogs and elite versions of most things. At the same time you get more tools and stances to deal with them, so the fights stay interesting instead of turning into mindless button mashing.

The one big issue is the mouse and keyboard controls. They are awkward. Switching to a controller is honestly night and day better. Combat feels great on flat ground, but it gets clunky whenever the terrain gets uneven. I have died so many times because I happened to be standing on a tiny rock the game treated like a three foot ledge and it refused to let me dodge or roll off it. Really frustrating.

Visuals

Even five years later the game looks incredible. Lighting, weather, landscapes, particle effects, forests, fields, storms, sunsets, everything looks amazing. Easily one of the best looking open world games out there, and the art direction carries it even harder than the graphics.

Story and samurai portrayal

The story is solid enough and kept me interested. It focuses on the Mongol expansion and takes place on a large Japanese island. But the portrayal of samurai is very romanticised. If you know anything about real samurai history, it is obvious how heavily idealised everything is. Samurai were not noble heroes of honour and virtue, and the game absolutely leans into that myth.

It even reaches the point where the main character has a whole moral dilemma over using stealth, as if real samurai would be against quietly killing enemies. In reality they did much, much worse things to their own people, never mind invading Mongols.

It is not a deal breaker though. As its own fictional take on the idea of samurai, it works fine. The characters are not cringey, the dialogue is decent, and it gets surprisingly brutal at times, which is refreshing considering how toned down a lot of modern games feel these days.

Final thoughts

Apart from the clunky mouse and keyboard controls, some annoying terrain issues and the overly romanticised samurai angle, Ghost of Tsushima is genuinely fantastic. I am not usually into open world games like this, but this one pulled me in fast.

A solid 9 out of 10 from someone who does not usually enjoy the genre.

Ghost of Tsushima opens with the classic battle of red laser vs. blue laser, er... I mean armor. You control Jinei, a fictional samurai perhaps loosely based on Sukesada or somehow supposed to be the Kamikaze, as he engages in a fully fictional retelling of the First Mongol Invasion of Japan. Sure, video game. Expect liberties, lots of liberties. This game largely feels like another Far Cry or modern Assassin's Creed, just with a different paint job. I wouldn't quite compare it to Witcher 3 or Horizon and certainly not to Skyrim. 

Open world games are about exploration. For the game to be good, that exploration must feed into the narrative or otherwise be exciting. Ghost of Tsushima's exploration largely does neither of these things. Instead, you are generally led to flat and extremely incremental buffs. There's just no sense of wonder while running around. To make things worse, the game actively hinders exploration by not making you aware of nearby landmarks unless you stop to open your map (and discover that you passed a handful so you have to turn around). Though, I will admit that finding an Inari Shrine that lets you pet a fox is great. So Cute! Come here and let me pet you. *ahem*

While running around, you'll find that this game also cannot decide what season it is. You have trees in full bloom (spring) and others with gold, orange, and red leaves falling (autumn). You have fireflies (early to mid summer) and chrysanthemums blooming (late summer and early autumn). Yes, these are part of the Japanese aesthetic, but they are for different times of the year and, aside from ephemeral beauty, hold different cultural meanings. Maybe they were some programmer's secret message that if this game were shorter, it would have been beautiful.

The other half of these games is beating things with sticks. Combat in Ghost of Tsushima is straight up deadly, just as you would hope from a samurai themed game. The stance switching for different kinds of opponents is really cool. Unfortunately, few of the unlocks for said stances (or almost any other technique) add anything interesting to the mix. Stances also suffer from using RT to swap, the same button for interaction, which means you might loot a corpse or crawl under a building when you are trying to change stances. This problem stems from trying to cram too many options into the controller. Sadly, the keyboard controls are not any better, as only minimal thought was given to the port.

Combat is not helped by the limited variety of enemies. Until midgame, there's essentially just four, and they vary by armor and speed; after that, they add ronin, who are simply faster, better versions than you. This means that what starts as an interesting combat system quickly becomes stale. I am unsure if its a bug or some hidden lock on feature, but while fighting I could often myself facing the opposite direction and running backwards as I tried to charge or swing at a particular foe. 

As gameplay is essentially broken into three modes (exploration, combat + stealth, and duels), the gear you use varies between all three. There is no penalty or inability for changing armor and charms at any time, so why not just codify gear sets that you can change to? It was obnoxious to be constantly swapping my gear when I went from combat to exploration and vice versa.

Amidst all of this are silly annoyances. For instance, when the game tells you that you are entering an area with an overwhelming number of foes, it will just kill you with arrows out of nowhere even after you've sniped the archers. In another instance, a quest tells you to search both paths for clues of which to take, only there are no clues and you don't get the instruction to trail a cart until you are right on top of it and cannot avoid being noticed. In fact, the searching for clues moments during investigations is the most frustrating thing in the game.

Where the open world it disenchanting and the combat quickly stale, the game is lifted up by moments. To say that Ghost of Tsushima is inspired by the Kurosawa films I love would be an understatement. Heck, there's a Kurosawa mode that gives it B&W film grain and voice static. But this is felt more so in particular moments that the game presents, like when you are about to engage in a duel or participate in a key story beat, like the retaking of Castle Kaneda. If the game just strung these moments together, it would have been amazing. Instead, these moments are too infrequent to be truly effective.

Central to the plot is the representation of honor. I had wanted to wait until I finished Ghost of Tsushima before I really dove in here, but the game is boring enough that I don't know when that will be, and I think I see the trajectory. Honor is originally presented in a childishly simple way that I hated. Killing from the front, with a bow, or with bees is honorable, as is stealing from peasants. Only backstabbing seems to be dishonorable. Fortunately, as the game progresses, the truth comes out: honor is a tool of the powerful to maintain their power. It provides the veneer of civility while consolidating power to prevent challenge. That which is dishonorable is often that which the less powerful could use against those in power. At the time of this writing, we see our character's uncle chastising him for dishonorable means, which have been successful and raised his acclaim among the peasants. This makes you a threat to the uncle and will likely lead to a confrontation. Ghost of Tsushima matures into this framework to in fact offer an excellent portrayal.

Overall, as much as I want to like this game, I cannot recommend it. Outside of its great moments, fox pets, and solid writing, it is boring. It is a game that tried to do a bit too much. Its open world exploration is disinteresting and its combat is ultimately stale. Sadly, those two items are the majority of the game.
